results.content:
Edwin takes you on a worth while journey thru PHP & PayPal. Definitely helped having some prior PHP experience, but his pace, examples, files, and breakdowns seemed helpful for newbies.

Thru this course, Edwin helped me figure out the main framework for setting up and connecting my e-commerce site to PayPal. I feel confident enough to find and answer my other e-commerce questions (shipping & handling, tax, invoice receipts, etc.). 

Highly recommended for intermediate PHP coders (or similar coding experience), and definitely recommended for newbies trying to set up an e-commerce site (or just learn PHP). Stick with the lectures. If something doesn't make sense, the Q&A is fantastic in the course, and Edwin usually comes back around to clear things up in the next lecture. Thanks again Edwin

results.content:
This course is an excellent follow-up to Edwin's other course, "PHP for Beginners".  However, it is VERY similar to the final project in that course, where you build a CMS.  Still, this course is worth it for its laser focus on that objective, and Edwin is an engaging, responsive teacher.

My only complaint is the lack of organization.  Refactoring is a useful skill, and I appreciate it the attention it gets in the course, but I wish it were more logical.  As it is it often seems like the topic for a given lecture is decided the moment the instructor hits "record".
results.content_html:
This course is an excellent follow-up to Edwin's other course, "PHP for Beginners". However, it is VERY similar to the final project in that course, where you build a CMS. Still, this course is worth it for its laser focus on that objective, and Edwin is an engaging, responsive teacher.

My only complaint is the lack of organization. Refactoring is a useful skill, and I appreciate it the attention it gets in the course, but I wish it were more logical. As it is it often seems like the topic for a given lecture is decided the moment the instructor hits "record".

results.content:
I am very very pleased with this course! I am not a professional developer and before this course I had some very basic PHP knowledge...I also learned a lot of the basics throughout this course (with my additional research).  

To be honest, I wasn't expecting such a nice experience. I love the short lectures, which are very well structured, in such a way that you can understand each step little by little. Edwin's explanations are pretty clear most of the time, the rhythm of coding is perfect, not too slow but not too fast either. Of course, you can always pause or rewind parts of the video. Every functionality of this application is super nice and the logic behind them is very clear. In the end, I had everything working just fine.

Another thing: I LOVE that you can see when the teacher makes some mistakes himself! He kind of gives you tricks how to debug your code faster and you also learn from his mistakes.

Also, I was surprised to discover that anytime I had a question or some problem regarding the code, the team behind this course was very nice and helpful. I always received an answer pretty fast. Of course, maybe not all of them were clear solutions, but still they helped me figure out what the problem was. You still can't expect someone else to debug your code all the time! So, I have a lot of appreciation to the team/the person that managed all the questions from the students, I think they are doing a great job.

Thank you!!

results.content:
Sometimes it's not easy to code along with the video because it is not always clearly shown which lines of code are cut and pasted (or copied/deleted) and from which place/file to where.
Also, not always detailed explanation is given about the way code works, for example while looping through the products to display those on the page or tracking values assigned to variables. 
Longer lines of code should have been wrapped into the next line, so they fit on the screen, otherwise you can't see the code at the end of the line and can only guess about it.
Lessons could have been better planned as there is an element of spontaneity in the way lessons are taught.
Besides this, there is certainly a lot you can learn from this course. "Edwin from the future" appearances are very entertaining :)
Paypal now uses some new JavaScript SDK payment processing script.

results.content:
It's a really good and well explained code-along for newbies to PHP, some of the methodologies used aren't the best, OOP is not used, MVC is ignored and Heredocs are used which ruins your indentation.

Some time is spend creating somewhat redundant functions to shorten the names of some longer pre-existing PHP functions, this is not really good practice either. But all of this is nitpicking from more advanced programmers, if you're relatively new and you couple this with other tutorials then this is a great entry level course for PHP, it's not worth anywhere near 200$ obviously as no course on Udemy honest is, but if you catch it for like 26 or so, get it, you'll learn a lot about making PHP websites.

results.content:
The concepts here are great and it's a great primer on how to include the PayPal API in your projects. That part (and how to manage inventory) is the most important part of the course, and probably what most of us are here for. Visually speaking, these parts could've been better executed, but obviously aesthetics are not pivotal in learning the main concepts here.

However, I had to take off half a star because I personally find this course to be a bit sloppy in organization. In my opinion, a lot of the lectures in the Launching It Online could've been eliminated had the architecture of the app been better planned out. That said, these mistakes are great vehicle for more thorough learning.

In conclusion, another great course from Edwin!

results.content:
Please understand- I had already taken a course in PHP before this class. It taught very little about MySQL or PHPmyAdmin. I was under the impression that I had enough understanding from that class, only to find that THIS particular course was most certainly more in depth than I ever imagined (that's a good thing, you WANT in-depth so you can actually know what you're talking about). I was so impressed, I also signed up for his beginner course (which, if you're used to university academia, you will quickly learn that neither of these courses are the typical "hello-world" to cheap OOP concepts- this is real world use here). I bought them at a discount with no regret. I would have paid full price for both- after all, I paid $1200 for a college-equivalent that barely gets a programmer to code his way out of even the simplest of problems. 

Top notch, Mr. Diaz.

results.content:
This is the second of Edwin's courses I've purchased and the same SQL vulnerabilities exist, across them both. I got stuck, a little, and went to Stack Overflow for advice, i posted my code and within minutes, I had half a dozen folk, jumping on it, telling me I'm vulnerable to SQL injections, as I'm not using prepare statements and my use of mysqli_escape_string is a poor substitute. The job I have had changing it, to a more secure system, has been unreal and if you're being taught how to create an ecommerce site, security should be of a paramount consideration.

My site isn't going live anywhere, so I just changed to MYSQLi prepare statements, but PDO is a serious consideration too. I know it's a beginners' course, but still, it wouldn't have been so much a of a task to start from something more secure. It's a shame, as Edwin is quite likeable and I enjoy his lectures, but they're let down by lack of security fundamentals.

results.content: Edwin knows his subject matter and he has a great teaching style. He is perfect except for one major flaw, he doesn't provide the completed code at the end of each lecture or at the very least at the end of each section. It is very difficult to follow what he does in the videos at times and it would help immensely to see the code without going over the video 20 times to get it right. If your code gets corrupted  somewhere along the course and you're not sure where you made the mistake, then having the code at the end of each lecture would help you recover and move on with the course. I never was able to complete my PHP for beginners course because of errors that I could never find, having the correct code at the end of each lecture would have got me up and running again.

results.content:
This course was great. The main reason I took this course is to learn the paypal integration, but I ended up learning a whole lot more! This is a great followup if you took Edwin's blog class.

Some familiarity with PHP is assumed; but honestly. If you've shell scripted before (if statements, loops, etc), you'll be fine.

Thoughts:

It seemed like the instructor did each lesson "on the fly". Meaning that it feels like he just hit record and talked his way through how he did each part.

1) Why this is bad: For me, this feels a little bit disorganized. He, at times, makes mistakes that he may or may not fix in future lessons. Sometimes you're debugging only to find out 2-3 lessons later that it wasn't YOU that was wrong :)

2) Why this is good: This is actually how real world programming works. As Edwin says; "Mistakes are good". Doing these lessons "on the fly" not only shows you the thought process behind it (the "why"); but also teaches you how to debug. Often times when you're just "copying the teacher" you're not really LEARNING. As frustrating as it is at times during the course, it's actually good in the long run.

Overall; great course if you want to get good at procedural PHP webdevelopment.
